intro.title: Did God create evil?
intro.description: There are those who believe that for good to exist, evil should also be created and experienced. However, this is not what the Bible says about God’s plan in creation.

appendix.appendixContent:
Jeremiah 29:11-13

11 For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, says the Lord, thoughts of peace and not of evil, to give you a future and a hope.12 Then you will call upon Me and go and pray to Me, and I will listen to you.13 And you will seek Me and find Me, when you search for Me with all your heart.

questions.description: The book of Genesis is very clear in pointing out that everything God created was “good” (Genesis 1:31). Jeremiah 29:11-13 also declares that God’s intentions and thoughts regarding His creatures have always been and are the best. Such behavior is often seen between parents and their children, objects of their love and reason for all their commitment and dedication.
questions.questionTitle: Since the creation of the world, God’s plans for humanity are always the best.
questions.questionVersicles: Read Jeremiah 29:11 and Genesis 1:31 and mark true or false on the following statements:

answers.text: God has thoughts of peace and not evil about us.
God created the world in a reasonable way.
The creation of the world was the work of chance.
God does not really care about us.

appendix.appendixContent:
Luke 11:11-13

11 If a son asks for bread from any father among you, will he give him a stone? Or if he asks for a fish, will he give him a serpent instead of a fish?12 Or if he asks for an egg, will he offer him a scorpion?13 If you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask Him!”

Luke 11:11-13

11 If a son asks for bread from any father among you, will he give him a stone? Or if he asks for a fish, will he give him a serpent instead of a fish?12 Or if he asks for an egg, will he offer him a scorpion?13 If you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask Him!”

questions.description: Psalm 5 reinforces this truth by saying that God has no covenant with wickedness (Psalm 5:4). He would never have created anything to harm or hurt His children. The New Testament reinforces this by saying that if earthly parents wish good things to their children; the Heavenly Father does much more! (Luke 11:11-13). However, even with all the perfection of the creation of the world and God’s best intentions and plans for mankind, the unfolding of history didn’t have only happy chapters. Sin came to humanity, destroying the initial perfection.
questions.questionTitle: Is it right then to say that God wants us to do better things than our own parents?
questions.questionAppendix: Read Luke 11:11-13 to answer

answers.text: It depends on the type of parents
answers.value: It depends on the type of parents

appendix.appendixContent:
II Peter 2:4

4 For if God did not spare the angels who sinned, but cast them down to hell and delivered them into chains of darkness, to be reserved for judgment;

Isaiah 14:14

14 I will ascend above the heights of the clouds, I will be like the Most High.’

questions.description: As incredible as it seems, the entrance of sin into the world is also related to the fact that God is love. He allowed the possibility of evil from the moment he decided to create free beings. And it was one of these creatures who misused freedom by disobeying God (1 John 3:8) by cultivating pride and presumption to take the place of the Creator (Isaiah 14:14). Peter though, confirms the account that heavenly creatures sinned (2 Peter 2:4). Sin came to mankind and with it its devastating consequences. However, we must understand what God’s desire and plan has always been for each of His children.
questions.questionTitle: Which of the following reasons is NOT related to the first sin?
questions.questionAppendix: Read Isaiah 14:14 to answer

answers.text: Intention to be similar to the Most High
answers.value: Intention to be similar to the Most High

appendix.appendixContent:
Ezekiel 33:11

11 Say to them: ‘As I live,’ says the Lord God, ‘I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked, but that the wicked turn from his way and live. Turn, turn from your evil ways! For why should you die, O house of Israel?’

questions.description: The Bible is clear in showing that death was never God’s plan, and it is also clear in saying that He has no pleasure in it (Ezekiel 33:11), since His pleasure has always been in giving and sustaining life.
